title: Am I required to complete a Schedule of Assets and Debts in a paternity case. We were never married but have two boys together.
question: Am I required to complete a Schedule of Assets and Debts? My ex-partner and I have no community property to split up so why should I complete it. On what grounds can I object to filling it out?
question_tags: Divorce,Dividing debts in a divorce,Community property in divorce,Child support,Divorce and bankruptcy,Child custody,Family court and child custody cases,Bankruptcy,Debt,Bankruptcy and debt,Divorce and family,Child support and custody,Paternity and child custody,Family law,Paternity
answers: The first question I would ask is, “Who is asking that you fill it out?” Did the judge order that? Did you receive discovery asking that you fill that out? If no one has demanded that of you, then why are you concerned. Just the other side sending you a blank and asking or telling you to fill it out is not enough to require you to do that.

If child support is an issue, you may be required to file an income and expense declaration. Schedule of Assets and debts may be required if you have high-value assets but low income. An argument can be made that the child should live in the same station of life that you live in.

There is no need for Assets and Debts in a paternity action. There may be, and probably is, the need for an Income and Expense Declaration (FL-150) as there may be the issue of child support to deal with.
No need for Schedule of Assets and Debts. But you do need to do the Income and Expense Declaration since it sounds like Child Support may be an issue.
